title: What I (a game designer) would change to improve League if I was in charge.
body:
**Dragons:
**
First off.. I'd change dragons so that they gave a "mini baron buff" to the players that participated in securing the objective.
I'd remove the 5 different types.



It is hard to get your team to help you secure one sometimes, much less get them to put their lanes in a position that you can solo one.
I've even dealt with jungles (or laners) that WILL NOT dragon because they don't care about it because it isn't Infernal/Mountain... 

A lot of times nobody will help because "It's just a mana/wind dragon"


This would also remove the random type mechanic which I feel can throw a match in turmoil especially when teams start stacking the right one (I.E. Zed has three infernals, Brand has three mana dragons)..

When a team has three of the same, it can do a lot for the right champs... it makes it harder for the other team to fight them at that point.
Especially if that team is already oppressive to fight.

A mini baron buff removes that RNG factor and encourages participation in the fight. It is a benefit that everyone can immediately see and makes securing it more important.


**Rift Scuttles**


The amount of gold and exp tied up in these things are atrocious. If you steal a single camp early game, get both scuttles and both your buffs... The other jungle is going to be playing catch up for a hot second if they can't get a gank in. I've been on both sides of this.

The high amount of gold also encourages your "team-mates" to come steal them, which makes it hard to stay on par or catch up if if you fall off.


The vision they provide makes it a nightmare to dragon/baron or gank nearby lanes if the other team kills it, especially if the other jungle is power clearing or the other team is more active in helping them.


I'd remove them from the game ultimately, but I'd also support lowering the spawn frequency drastically, and/or lowering the amount gold/exp they provide.


**Rift Herald**

Nothing like losing an entire lane to this thing because the other team gets it and no one wants to help prevent it from shoving down your lane.

I'd either remove this completely or change the reward for defeating it.

I think some kind of buff and a mass amount of gold/exp would be more appropriate.


There is enough going on the in the game, that a successful rift herald shouldn't  practically end the match.


**Wall Jumpers**

Kayn, Talon, Akali, etc etc


This shit is ridiculous sometimes. Most of the champs that can do it, quite often have no problem completely wiping you out in a straight fight anyway.. so it makes it SUPER FRUSTRATING when they can easily kill you anyway, but the moment you get them close to dying, they just escape through a wall.

I'm not saying I'd remove this completely. I think some champs can use it really well and it provides some interesting gameplay.

Talon at least can't jump the same wall twice for a period of time... Kayn however can free-run across the map.. 

Kayn jungle can be oppressive because he just shortcuts across the map and clears the entire board before you walk to your second/third camp.
I can't count the number of times I've cleared three camps just to find Kayn clear my other half of the jungle. By the time you discover it, he has cleared the rest of his.


What I'd do with these champs is lower the overall frequency of wall hoping so that it has to be a strategic choice and not a "get out of jail free card"

I have no problem with Graves or similar champs being able to use his E to jump through a wall, but being able to cover vast distances provides too much mobility.


**FIRST BLOOD and early kills/Snowballing**


First blood should be rewarding.. but league is one of those games where a single kill can cause the killer to snowball out of control. I'd change the game mechanics overall to award a small buff for getting first blood. 

In addition a team getting a few kills early shouldn't determine the majority of a game. I'd lower the worth of early kills.

This would encourage players to participate in early fights and minimize the impact of a failed/successful invade.


Players tend to FREAK THE FUCK OUT when someone on the team dies. Lowering the value of kills early would provide a safety net for error.

Also.. players sometimes put too much effort into trying to get kills, rather than trying to secure objectives.

I'd handle this potentially in several different ways.

1. First 10 kills overall are practically worthless with a slowly ramp up in value. 

Going with this, it would provide a fair amount across the board to prevent any one player from being targeted.

2. A players first 3 deaths award little gold and afterwards full value.

This would give each player equal chance of lowering their impact to the enemy.. but at risk of being a major target (Lets all gank Mid because he's died 3 times)

3. Kills are worth a little more than siege minions, but offer higher experience points. 

The reward here is a little bit of gold and an increase in levels. This would lower the impact of a player getting "FED AF" because they wouldn't be stacking items while everyone is still finishing the first. Giving a lot of experience would give them a level advantage, rather than an Item advantage, which would allow the losing player to play smarter...

4. Kills are worth more early, but become worth less later.

I'm of the opinion that at 10 kills, you've probably got enough, and should probably be trying to get the rest of the team fed at this point.

Players become ABSOLUTELY obsessed with kills over objectives sometimes.

I've lost a lot of games because a midlaner is spending more time roaming than protecting their tower. It is incredibly frustrating to watch a player leave lane to chase a kill and lose a tower each time they do.

Kills would be almost triple their current value on the first three, and worth about the same as an assist at 10 kills..each kill after that would reduce their value until they were worth the same as a siege minion.


Case 4 would be one of the more optimal paths because it would encourage focusing on objectives instead of a KDA. After 10 kills, you are going to start looking to end the match, and more profitable solutions.. (CS, Objectives, ETC)

Some champs with the right items can just nuke you under your tower if they get a good 3-4 kills on you in the current system..


**Remakes, Surrenders, Match Integrity**


First.. The Remake window is too short. It should also never be put to a vote. If a player is AFK and the system detects it.. The match needs to end.

Also the AFK player needs to be ANNOUNCED right away to both teams.

"PLAYER NAME is AFK, match will end in 5 minutes if they do not return"


In addition.. the remake period needs to extend to at least 10 minutes, and include situations where a player was present, but AFK'd after purchasing items.


FF@15 needs to go. I'm tired of the other team getting First Blood and someone on my team deciding the match is over.


AFK matches need to end with loss prevented. If a player AFKs they have 5 minutes to return or it ends. No more 4v5's

To prevent the "Getting a friend to afk" abuse riot is scared of.. this would be a simple fix:

Every player has a visible "LEAVER LEVEL" to alert them of how high their AFK levels are. 

Blind matches, Draft, etc would have a lower impact on their score. RANKED matches would have an EXTREMELY HIGH impact and about 3 AFKs in ranked would result in maxing the level out.


When the leaver level is high.. RANKED would be unavailable for say 10 games and consistently high or excessive levels would result in stricter punishments. This would be balanced around allowing room for circumstances beyond a players control and malicious AFKing.

The 3x in ranked would stand, because even RIOT has said that if you are having issues with your connection, you shouldn't be playing ranked.

If an AFK is worth 10 points.. it should take 20 games without an AFK to clear that off. (2 points per game.) 33 points for an AFK in ranked (33 x 3 =100). Points should also decay per day to help in situations where say a players connection was faulty one week and they had a higher score than they would normally.. this allows them to take a few days off play to ensure their connection is ok and give room to test it.

The week of a patch would also have a smaller impact on Leaver Levels to accommodate the issues that arise.

**Weekly Rotating Bans**

There are a lot of champs in this game.

To the point I feel like you could give each play 5 bans.. and still face a hardcounter in your lane. 

Not only are there a lot of champions.. but you consistently see the same champions every day.. day in.. day out.

It would be nice to see about 20 champions per week be Auto-Banned.


This would give a total of 30 potential bans per match.


In addition.. players would have to be able to play more champions and have a more diverse champion pool.

I've felt the requirements to entry into ranked are too low.


**Ranked Requirements**


I'd make the following changes (based on current system)

40 champions owned.

Level 99

Mastery 5 + champions only (40 champs at Mastery 5)
(This is because ranked shouldn't be the place you are first timing a pick)

These changes would give a little balance.. level 30 doesn't take long to reach anymore and is barely enough time to master a few mechanics, much less the ones you need to be successful.. this would also make your account more valuable.. and probably discourage people from the "I'll just make a new account mentality" 


**Starting Items**

I'd add a few options in there to diversify against a wider range of opponents.

I'd like to see MR and Attack Speed starting items. As well as HP/Mana Regen


**Mana Potions/Clarity**

These would come back... mana champs really suffer when they get matched up against non-mana champs.


**Jungle**

Nothing sucks more than having a player swipe up a camp that you are trying to fight.

I'd change jungle so that if the jungler is within a certain distance, they receive the gold/exp for the camp.

This would especially be handy for leashes.. because I'm always super nervous some troll is going to steal my camp.


If I'm taking 10g less for CSing their lanes.. they shouldn't be farming mine.




I thought I had more.. but I'll stop here for now.

replies.body: All I can say is good thing you’re not in charge of the LoL design team lol
I mean.. this is just my opinion.. feel free to present a constructive version of your own.

There are a lot of ideas here I feel would be actively detrimental or fail to do the full analysis I would expect of a game designer.

Dragon, for example, is an objective that is supposed to provide some early value but scale into a late-game advantage the more you are able to secure it. The stacking bonus provides an ability to close out games, which the extra value the *first* dragon gives means it functions as a comeback mechanic as well.

Converting this into a miniature Baron buff effectively removes the late-game scaling from Dragon, and makes it merely a tool for pushing early -- something Herald already accomplishes. By removing Herald and changing Dragon you effectively just move Herald's effect but allow it to impact *multiple* lanes instead of one.

>Nothing like losing an entire lane to this thing because the other team gets it and no one wants to help prevent it from shoving down your lane.

You neglect to mention here the incredible bonus damage you get from being behind Herald. A single person can reduce it's damage to just two plates (the original impact damage) by finding that opening. A successful Herald doesn't end the match -- it just sometimes gets you 1/2 to 1 tower, and more only if the enemy team is really inattentive.

>so it makes it SUPER FRUSTRATING when they can easily kill you anyway, but the moment you get them close to dying, they just escape through a wall.

Mobility is baked into those champions power budgets, and mobility is limited by both resource cost and spell cooldowns. Changing that has a *huge* impact on every aspect of the game's ecosystem, and addressing the magnitude of those changes in a few sentences is...a bit ridiculous.

I don't have the time right now to dig into the rest, but there's a lot here that seems to fundamentally alter many elements of the game for what I think are inadequately presented reasons. This reads less like the carefully considered proposal of a game designer and more like a list of things you dislike.

Most of my proposed changes are along the lines of leagues early seasons. I feel like its been a downhill shove since season 4... Season 3 was probably the best season in my opinion. These are based on what I've experienced both winning and losing around in the games I've played/spectated.

As far as my thoughts on dragon..

I'd at least cut back the types of dragons down to three... maybe mountain/infernal/cloud.

With the "mini baron buff" I proposed.. I'm thinking more a benefit in being able to port faster, have some better regen, and a temporary boost to damage.. it wouldn't last nearly as long. I don't think it should give the minions any more effectiveness. Just kind of like a combination of red/blue buff with something special to it.


Trading an entire games length worth of buffs for temporary ones that are more immediately effective. A strong offensive team can use that to their advantage and a strong defensive team can eliminate the buffed players and bring the match back into balance.


This would give incentive for you to ward your lanes better and communicate missing more effectively.


For the life of me I can not understand how 5 players go missing and an entire team fails to realize that they are either at dragon or baron.


The RNG of the dragons is really the main culprit.. Losing 3 infernals compared to 3 clouds has an entirely different impact on a game depending on the other teams comp.

Every factor in this game increases a players strength/weakness.

It can be hard to stay on par with your opponent when killing you is already an advantage.. sometimes games reach a point to where a single champion can just delete your whole team because they got a few kills.. and now this dragon is making them even harder to kill.




As far as herald goes.. I'm more concerned with eliminating the amount of stretching it feels like a Jungler experiences. As well as attempting to balance out for when your jungle doesn't attempt any objective control.

I'm partial to jungle but I play all the roles (adc the least) and it feels like that is the one role with the most work in a match. I've got to be able to balance farming, ganking, counter jg, objective control, vision control and lane sitting for 4 players.. focusing any one of those areas leaves a deficiency in the other... especially if your team just isn't co-operating.


Getting rid of Herald would just give a little breathing room.

I loved herald when it first hit the scene.. but I've come to the point that it frustrates me. Here is something that I can't afford to lose, I've got to constantly keep tabs on and if the other team gets it... I've now got to be ready to drop everything I'm doing and potentially run across the other end of the map to handle... If I'm dead or say bot in a fight when it drops top.. then it can potentially wreck havok. Especially if that lanes player is constantly chasing kills.


I've played three games tonight alone where a player was all the way in the opposite lane while the rift was shoving down their lane.



I know the game changes across different skill levels... but I can only speak from my experience.

This mechanic is a nightmare from where I'm sitting.

> [{quoted}](name=Sylias Ravenmore,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=6HbK89an,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2019-07-26T06:21:28.002+0000)I feel like its been a downhill shove since season 4... Season 3 was probably the best season in my opinion.

A *lot* has changed since then, both in terms of the options that exists, the skills of the playerbase, and the philosophy of the game's design. Season 2 and 3 were the heyday of the bruiser and assassin metas, where abilities tended to just land and targets tended to blow up quickly. There wasn't anywhere near as much skill expression in individual kits, and the large similarities in functionality between them.

While some people miss that, *League* has intentionally moved in a direction that offers more skill expression in their designs, which often means that -- used well -- those characters can do a lot. I'd honestly argue we're probably at one of the *healthiest* states of *League* as far as comeback potential, viability of a large number of champions, and evolving metagames. Is it perfect? Not at all. But I think it's a big improvement over Season 3.

> Trading an entire games length worth of buffs for temporary ones that are more immediately effective. A strong offensive team can use that to their advantage and a strong defensive team can eliminate the buffed players and bring the match back into balance.

This skews heavily towards early-game teams though, as later-game teams won't have the power needed to handle a buffed opponent (and are more likely to lose Dragon). With Dragon as a scaling mechanism an early-game team can secure an early advantage but a late-game team that gets one still gets power when it's important to them. By swapping that for a shorter-duration one-time buff you simply let early game teams snowball their advantage more, while late-game teams find that an early Dragon isn't actually useful by comparison.

> This would give incentive for you to ward your lanes better and communicate missing more effectively.
> For the life of me I can not understand how 5 players go missing and an entire team fails to realize that they are either at dragon or baron.

There's already *huge* incentives for this. Vision and communication almost *directly* win games. Now, vision and communication aren't properly appreciated at all levels of play, but that's a feature of the game, not a bug. As players improve, they will get better and learn these things. Removing valuable gameplay elements because some players don't appreciate them would be like removing the Knight from Chess just because it confuses beginners.

> The RNG of the dragons is really the main culprit.. Losing 3 infernals compared to 3 clouds has an entirely different impact on a game depending on the other teams comp.


> It can be hard to stay on par with your opponent when killing you is already an advantage.. sometimes games reach a point to where a single champion can just delete your whole team because they got a few kills.. and now this dragon is making them even harder to kill.

But by that point you've already lost a number of fronts. *League* does intentionally have some snowball mechanics -- and some anti-snowball mechanics -- so that games that are basically decided can end faster. If you let, say, a Jax get 5 kills and let his team get a few Dragons, that's not a flaw of the game -- that's your team not managing to control a hard-scaling carry.

> As far as herald goes.. I'm more concerned with eliminating the amount of stretching it feels like a Jungler experiences. As well as attempting to balance out for when your jungle doesn't attempt any objective control.

The game shouldn't balance for junglers who don't play for objectives, much like it shouldn't balance for carries who don't know how to last hit. Those are skills that need to be acquired to play the game, and compensating for failure to do those things ends up teaching people that you don't HAVE to play the game. That's the opposite of what you want in a competitive, skill-and-macro-decision-based game, because it tells players that objectives don't matter.

This is very confusing. You said you're a game designer, and you said you've worked in the industry for 15 years (writing for 20 years), but now you're distancing yourself from the notion that you're a professional game designer? Is this similar to someone claiming to be a stockbroker who's worked in the stockbroking industry for 15 years, but what they really mean is that they got a gift of one share of Disney stock for their fifth birthday and now they're 20 years old?

As far as I can tell from what you said earlier, you've never worked on a single completed project, and implied that you rarely do anything that could even go on your resume. Never mind being paid by a game development studio for game design work, never mind being paid by a game development studio for work unrelated to game design... are you employed in any capacity? Are you in school? Some other situation, perhaps (no need to specify)?

What does the phrase "I am a game designer" mean to you? What does "worked in the industry" mean to you? What does "professional" mean to you?

Did you intend to sabotage everything about your own credibility, or was this by accident?

I've worked in the industry yes. However, I've not worked for any AAA companies... unless you count my internship at Blizzard.. but there was nothing really to that other than running errands for people and making copies.. Every now and again I'd get to do something "fun" like Quality Assurance (here kid, run around this empty room for 3 hours and report any glitches you find in the animation cycles".

Most of my digital game design work has been with startups and indie development groups. Outside of the tabletop industry.



I never once said I was a professional game designer. Just someone that is a game designer.

I guess to break it down...because saying I'm a game designer gives the magical opinion that I have had to work for some big fancy AAA company..

A mechanic can work on cars, but that doesn't mean he works for NASCAR.

The ENTIRE point of this post was what I would change, as a game designer, if I was the one making the decisions. 



As far as my credentials go. I graduated from high school at the age of 16 with a certification in graphic design. I immediately took a fullride to the Art Institute of PA for 3 years (where I interned for Blizzard through their programs) and left there to continue education at UAT because I felt it offered a better end result (AI was trying to pin me into 2d graphics and I had specifically told them I wanted to learn 3D). 

My first game design job was for a company building an MMO called ANEPSOSIS back in 2004. I did the entirety of the concept art and assisted with modular 3d assets (environmental). I also was in charge of writing out the interactions of magical effects. The lead programmer left the project and had been paid ahead of time leaving no room in the budget to hire another one. We still didn't have networking coded and it was grim. Two months later, the project closed out.

Shortly after I hooked up with a crew doing your typical "zombie fps" the project ran into a massive case of feature creep.. (What if the zombies skin could melt, what if you could do this) and the publisher finally got tired of the lack of results and dropped it. The assets were either returned or sold off and divided up to cover contracts. I worked entirely on Lighting and as a 2D lead.

I took a break from digital games for a few years and hooked up with a few startups doing tabletop. The first one was a wargame/rpg and it was a 4 man team. We started promoting it heavily and contacted a few publishers to accept us. Wizards returned our call and offered to buy it out completely. We were excited. We wouldn't be on the design team anymore.. but the money was good and we'd be able to say "we made that". So we took the offer. The game never shipped, and when contacted, they told our lead that they determined "It wasn't a profitable venture at this time after further analysis"

Same story two years later, except we had less material.. It was a tactical card game. We were told that we would get to retain our positions in development and that our company would become a subsidiary of theirs. Three months in we get calls saying they are no longer pursuing the concept.

Rinse and repeat for about a hundred other jobs. I'm still looking for my break in the industry.. but its hard. Anything stable is generally looking for someone that has way more credentials than I've got. The AAA studios generally only hire people who have already shipped a title. At my stage you either take offers for "pay after the product makes money" or you subcontract out for small parts where you can tell a company.. "I built the dinosaur you see for two seconds on level 3"

It's a rough industry.. especially if your life plans prevent you from moving to where the studios are located.


To get into the actual designer positions you have to work your way up through other areas. Most of the time as a "Game Designer" you are also working in the art/programming department because everyone has ideas.

As of right now though.. I'm doing a subcontract for a studio producing assets. That will be my first completed project. I'm also working on my own stuff. I have my own company for my own products.

I can't work in full capacity though, I'm fully disabled.. so I'm a game designer by hobby.

I don't have anything at the moment, true.. I'd be happy to send you a demo later.. other than that I just have screenshots and work samples.. I can also link you to my world anvil page where my writing project is.

Not much there though because I just recently discovered the service and I've only tried to throw up articles online of well established plot lines. I was also wary of putting my work on the page at first because I didn't want it to get stolen.. but I'm not worried now because I'm confident in the protection the site offers. They've already sued on behalf of other users.

It's just a matter of sorting everything out. If you want to check out what is online, I'll pm you a link. Like I said though.. it's potentially in the process of a major rewrite.. and the majority hasn't been uploaded yet. I think there is enough there though to show that the scale of the work is massive.. which would lead to understanding on why it's taken so long.
